A recent moment where I relied on an AI tool was when I was choosing between two different software subscriptions for work. Both options seemed good on the surface, but each had different features, pricing tiers, and long-term commitments. I felt myself getting stuck in the usual loop of overthinking comparing tiny details, worrying I'd regret picking the wrong one, and bouncing between multiple tabs. I turned to an AI tool because I wanted a neutral breakdown without the stress spiral. Instead of sifting through reviews for an hour, the AI summarized the key differencs, highlighted what mattered most based on my needs, and pointed out potential drawbacks I hadn't considered. It didn't make the decision forme, but it made the path to a decision feel clearer. The main reason I chose AI in that moment was the convenience: it was fast, organized the information better than I could on my own, and removed a lot of the emotional noise from the process.
